awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyberinfrastructure Leadership Academy workshop's objective is to prepare a new generation of national Cyberinfrastructure (CI) leaders who can shape the national CI agenda, in order to promote the progress of science, which depend heavily and increasingly on the advanced digital capabilities that CI provides. The mechanism for accomplishing this goal is establishing mentoring relationships between senior CI leaders who are nearing retirement or recently retired, and emerging midcareer CI leaders. A mushrooming fraction of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education, research, development and commerce is computing- and/or data-intensive, and therefore depends on CI. The CI workforce pipeline has several stages, and one of the most vital, senior CI leaders, is rapidly narrowing as Baby Boomers retire. This outmigration presents a significant challenge to the burgeoning computing- and data-intensive research community, which depends heavily on senior CI leaders not only to oversee CI design, development, implementation and facilitation, but also to shape the research CI ecosystem and agenda, both locally at their own institutions and especially nationally. Crucial to surviving this expertise drain is capturing as much of that expertise as possible, before it is irretrievably lost. Establishing mentoring relationships between senior CI leaders and emerging midcareer CI leaders is invaluable, because such relationships not only enable the transfer of knowledge, experience and wisdom, but also serve to solidify the ability of emerging CI leaders to continue to draw on the expertise of senior CI leaders even after the latter retire.  To date, little emphasis has been placed on the senior end of the pipeline. The CI Leadership Academy workshop's intends to address this gap, by stanching the outflow of CI agenda/ecosystem/community expertise.

The Cyberinfrastructure Leadership Academy workshop takes the approach of convening a combination of senior CI leaders, many of whom are nearing retirement or have recently retired, and emerging midcareer CI leaders, to meet the following objectives: (1) Transfer knowledge, experience and especially wisdom from senior CI leaders to emerging CI leaders, in order to enable emerging CI leaders to shape the national research CI landscape. (2) Initiate mentoring relationships between senior CI leaders and emerging CI leaders, in order to foster longer term professional development. (3) Establish peer mentoring relationships among emerging CI leaders, in order to prepare and position them for national leadership, as senior CI leaders reduce their day to day engagement. Important components of this workshop's process include: (a) White papers from the senior and emerging CI leaders on topics directly relevant to the national research CI ecosystem/community are a valuable component in mentorship matchmaking, by helping senior and emerging CI leaders to understand each other. (b) Perspective panels offer the viewpoints of stakeholders such as research funding agencies, industry, and researcher constituencies. (c) Brief talks by senior CI leaders on their experiences, and sit-downs between senior CI leaders and emerging midcareer leaders, are designed to establish both professional and personal linkages. This workshop includes a focus on emerging CI leaders from populations that have traditionally been underrepresented in CI leadership, including (a) women, (b) underrepresented minorities, (c) Minority Serving Institutions, (d) non-PhD-granting institutions, and (e) institutions in EPSCoR jurisdictions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) research Cyberinfrastructure (CI) workforce pipeline has several stages, and one of the most crucial, senior/national CI leaders, is rapidly narrowing as Baby Boomers retire. This outmigration presents a significant challenge to the burgeoning computing/data-intensive research community, which depends heavily on senior/national CI leaders, not only to oversee research CI design, development, implementation and facilitation, but also to shape the research CI ecosystem and agenda, both locally at their own institutions and nationally.

Crucial to surviving this expertise drain is capturing as much of that expertise as possible, before it is irretrievably lost. A valuable mechanism for this is to establish (i) sustained mentoring relationships between senior/national CI leaders and emerging/institutional CI leaders, and (ii) peer-mentoring relationships among emerging/institutional CI leaders, because these relationships not only enable the transfer of knowledge, experience and wisdom, but also solidify the ability of the emerging/institutional CI leaders to continue to draw on the expertise of the senior/national CI leaders even after they retire.

The CI Leadership Academy (CILA) addresses this gap, by ensuring that this critical knowledge is preserved and passed on to the next generation of national CI leaders, thereby stanching the outflow of CI agenda/ecosystem/community expertise. Specifically, the CI Leadership Academy has conducted two workshops that have convened both (a) senior/national CI leaders, some of whom have retired or will soon retire, and (b) emerging/institutional CI leaders, in order to: 

(1) transfer knowledge and especially wisdom and experience from senior/national CI leaders to emerging/institutional CI leaders, because this enables emerging/institutional CI leaders to shape the national research CI landscape; 

(2) initiate mentoring relationships between senior/national CI leaders and emerging/institutional CI leaders, because this fosters longer term professional development; 

(3) establish peer mentoring relationships among emerging/institutional CI leaders, because this better prepares and positions them for national leadership, as senior/national CI leaders reduce their engagement.

This CILA grant funded a pair of two-day workshops, hosting a total of 16 senior/national CI leaders, 27 emerging/institutional CI leaders, and several guests (e.g., program officers, researchers, institutional officers). Of the 43 total CI leader participants, 33% were women, 9% were African American, 9% were at Minority Serving Institutions, 5% were at non-PhD-granting institutions, and 19% were at institutions in Established Program for the Stimulation of Competitive Research (EPSCoR) jurisdictions.

The Feb 2019 two-day CILA workshop hosted 34 participants, and the two-day workshop in March 2022 hosted 29 participants. The 2019 workshop was held at the University of Oklahoma on Feb 26-27 2019. The March 2022 CILA workshop was held entirely on Zoom (because of the tail end of COVID-19) on March 2-3 2022.

Collectively, the two CI Leadership Academy workshops had a total of 47 attendees and organizers and 21 guest panelists. Including the workshop organizers, 17 of the 47 participants and organizers (26%) were each from one or more traditionally underrepresented populations: 1 underrepresented minority woman; 3 underrepresented minority men; 1 disabled woman; 12 non-underrepresented-minority non-disabled women.

There were also 3 participants (6%) from Minority Serving Institutions (one of which is also a non-PhD-granting institution), 1 participant (2%) from non-MSI non-PhD-granting institutions, and 11 participants (23%) from EPSCoR jurisdictions.

Thus, in total, 25 of the 47 participants (53%) were either themselves as individuals from populations that have traditionally been underrepresented in CI, and/or from institution types that have traditionally been underrepresented in CI.


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Henry J Neeman

(2) initiate mentoring relationships between senior/national CI leaders and emerging/institutional CI leaders, because this fosters longer term professional development;
